elements.content: A stable two-dimensional (2D) coordination Cd­(II) polymer [Cd­(ppvppa)­(1,4-NDC)] n (1) (ppvppa = N-(pyridin-2-yl)-N-(4-(2-(pyridin-4-yl)­vinyl)­phenyl)­pyridin-2-amine; 1,4-H2NDC = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid) was prepared by the solvothermal reactions of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with ppvppa and 1,4-H2NDC in H2O and MeCN at 150 °C. Compound 1 was characterized by elemental analysis, IR, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and single crystal X-ray diffraction and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Compound 1 consists of dimeric [Cd2(μ-ppvppa)2] fragments linked by 1,4-NDC bridges to generate a 2D honeycomb network. Complex 1 strongly emits blue light in the solid state when excited at 419 nm at ambient temperature. This emission is selectively quenched by nitro aromatic compounds in water with good sensitivity. Compound 1 also displays recyclable detection of nitro aromatic compounds.

elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2NDC) and N-(pyridin-2-yl)-N-(4-(2-(pyridin-4-yl)­vinyl)­phenyl)­pyridin-2-amine (ppvppa) in H2O and MeCN at 150 °C afforded one stable two-dimensional coordination polymer {Cd­(ppvppa)­(1,4-NDC)} n , which demonstrates highly selective and sensitive detection of 2,4-DNP among nitro aromatic compounds via energy transfer, electron transfer, and electrostatic interaction in water.

elements.content: Detection of nitroaromatic compounds is important for national homeland security, military applications, forensic investigations, and environmental protection. These compounds are both environmental pollutants and potentially explosive. Current detection methods rely on trained sniffer dogs or sophisticated instruments including gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry, surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy, nuclear quadrupole resonance, energy dispersive X-ray diffraction, neutron activation analysis, electron capture detection, and cyclic voltammetry. These approaches need very expensive instruments, and they are not easily accessible in most cases. A sensitive, optical detection method would be simpler, quicker, and less expensive and could potentially be employed both in solution and the solid phase. Electron-deficient nitroaromatic compounds are strong quenchers of electron-rich fluorophores via a charge-transfer mechanism. Numerous conjugated organic molecules, polymers, and nanoscale materials have been used for this purpose. Very recently, fluorescent coordination polymers (CPs) or metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have proved to be attractive candidates for the detection of trace amounts of nitroaromatics. Li et al. reported a microporous crystalline MOF material that could detect 2,4-dinitrotoluene and 2,3-dimethyl-2,3-dinitrobutane in the vapor phase. The CP-based fluorescent detection can be efficiently modulated by both analyte–metal and analyte–ligand interactions and displays fast, highly sensitive, and reversible nitro-explosives sensing compared with other methods. However, most luminescent CP materials are used to detect nitroaromatics in organic solvents. An optical detection method for use at, for example, the site of suspected water contamination could be very useful but would obviously require suitable, water-stable CPs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Detection of nitroaromatic compounds is important for national homeland security, military applications, forensic investigations, and environmental protection. These compounds are both environmental pollutants and potentially explosive. Current detection methods rely on trained sniffer dogs or sophisticated instruments including gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry, surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy, nuclear quadrupole resonance, energy dispersive X-ray diffraction, neutron activation analysis, electron capture detection, and cyclic voltammetry. These approaches need very expensive instruments, and they are not easily accessible in most cases. A sensitive, optical detection method would be simpler, quicker, and less expensive and could potentially be employed both in solution and the solid phase. Electron-deficient nitroaromatic compounds are strong quenchers of electron-rich fluorophores via a charge-transfer mechanism. Numerous conjugated organic molecules, polymers, and nanoscale materials have been used for this purpose. Very recently, fluorescent coordination polymers (CPs) or metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have proved to be attractive candidates for the detection of trace amounts of nitroaromatics. Li et al. reported a microporous crystalline MOF material that could detect 2,4-dinitrotoluene and 2,3-dimethyl-2,3-dinitrobutane in the vapor phase. The CP-based fluorescent detection can be efficiently modulated by both analyte-metal and analyte-ligand interactions and displays fast, highly sensitive, and reversible nitro-explosives sensing compared with other methods. However, most luminescent CP materials are used to detect nitroaromatics in organic solvents. An optical detection method for use at, for example, the site of suspected water contamination could be very useful but would obviously require suitable, water-stable CPs.

elements.content: The luminescent behavior of a CP is highly dependent on the choice of organic ligand and metal ion. Hence, the highly selective and sensitive sensing of nitroaromatics can be achieved by the careful selection of the organic building block and the nature of the metal. In this paper, we report the design and synthesis of a bis­(2-pyridyl)-amine ligand for coordination to Cd for efficient detection of nitroaromatics. The ligand N-(pyridin-2-yl)-N-(4-(2-(pyridin-4-yl)­vinyl)­phenyl)­pyridin-2-amine (ppvppa) possesses three pyridyl rings, one carbon–carbon double bond, and a triarylamine group based on the following reasons. First, triarylamine derivatives possessing aromatic π rings and nitrogen atoms with lone-pair electrons can adjust the position of ligands to provide intraligand interactions, promote luminescent character, strongly bind metal ions, and are highly emissive. Moreover, it is electron rich, facilitating the nitroaromatic detection. Importantly, CdII is a d10 metal ion that displays a high complexation affinity to carboxylate and does not interfere with the fluorescence of organic ligands. With these considerations in mind, we carried out the solvothermal reaction of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with ppvppa and 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2NDC) at 150 °C in H2O and MeCN, and isolated the one two-dimensional (2D) coordination Cd­(II) polymer [Cd­(ppvppa)­(1,4-NDC)] n (1). Compound 1 is very stable in water and exhibits highly selective detection of nitroaromatics in aqueous media through a fluorescence quenching mechanism.

elements.content: All chemicals and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. The flash column chromatography was carried out on silica gel (300–400 mesh). Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Carlo-Erba CHNO-S microanalyzer. Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400–4000 cm–1) on a PerkinElmer model 1320 spectrometer. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra in DMSO-d 6 were recorded at ambient temperature on a Varian UNITY plus-400 spectrometer. The 13C NMR, 1H–1H COSY, and 1H–13C COSY NMR spectra of ppvppa ligand in DMSO-d 6 were recorded at ambient temperature on a Agilent NMR Systems 600 MHz NMR spectrometer. The 1H and 13C NMR chemical shifts were referenced to the solvent signal in DMSO-d 6. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was obtained on a Mettler Toledo Star System (heating rate of 5 °C/min). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60). The UV–vis absorption spectra of nitro derivatives were measured on a Varian Cary-50 UV–visible spectrophotometer. The photoluminescent spectra were obtained on a PerkinElmer LS55 spectrofluorometer or a Varian Cary-Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. High-resolution mass spectra were obtained by using a Microma GCT-TOF instrument. The uncorrected melting points were measured on a Mel-Temo II apparatus. The electrospray ion mass spectrum (ESI-MS) was recorded on an Agilent 1200/6200 mass spectrometer. The solid-state optical absorption spectra for powder samples were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-3150 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere by using BaSO4 as a white standard at room temperature in the range of 200–800 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

General Procedure

All chemicals and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. The flash column chromatography was carried out on silica gel (300-400 mesh). Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Carlo-Erba CHNO-S microanalyzer. Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400-4000 cm-1) on a PerkinElmer model 1320 spectrometer. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra in DMSO-d 6 were recorded at ambient temperature on a Varian UNITY plus-400 spectrometer. The 13C NMR, 1H-1H COSY, and 1H-13C COSY NMR spectra of ppvppa ligand in DMSO-d 6 were recorded at ambient temperature on a Agilent NMR Systems 600 MHz NMR spectrometer. The 1H and 13C NMR chemical shifts were referenced to the solvent signal in DMSO-d 6. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was obtained on a Mettler Toledo Star System (heating rate of 5 °C/min). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60). The UV-vis absorption spectra of nitro derivatives were measured on a Varian Cary-50 UV-visible spectrophotometer. The photoluminescent spectra were obtained on a PerkinElmer LS55 spectrofluorometer or a Varian Cary-Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer. High-resolution mass spectra were obtained by using a Microma GCT-TOF instrument. The uncorrected melting points were measured on a Mel-Temo II apparatus. The electrospray ion mass spectrum (ESI-MS) was recorded on an Agilent 1200/6200 mass spectrometer. The solid-state optical absorption spectra for powder samples were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-3150 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere by using BaSO4 as a white standard at room temperature in the range of 200-800 nm.

elements.content: A mixture of 2,2′-dipyridylamine (1.97 g, 11.5 mmol), 1,4-diiodobenzene (7.588 g, 23 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.41 g, 2 mmol), cesium carbonate (1.15 g, 3.5 mmol), and copper­(I) iodide (0.152 g, 0.8 mmol) in 100 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) was placed in a 500 mL round-bottom flask and heated to 160 °C under N2 atmosphere for 48 h. The reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature, and DMF was removed under reduced pressure. Dichloromethane and water were used to dissolve the solids, and the organic phase was separated and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The crude product was purified by flash silica gel column chromatography using petroleum ether and ethyl acetate (1:10) as the eluent to afford a white solid. Yield: 2.64 g (60%). mp 98.8–99.6 °C; IR (KBr disk): 3009 (m), 1586 (m), 1567 (m), 1530 (m), 1483 (m), 1465 (s), 1428 (s), 1329 (s), 1270 (m), 1151 (m), 1096 (m), 1052 (m), 1006 (m), 988 (m), 823 (m), 762 (m), 735 (m), 714 (m), 647 (m), 615 (m), 525 (m), 509 (m) cm–1 (). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 8.23 (d, 2H, J = 4.0 Hz), 7.69 (m, 4H), 7.05 (m, 2H), 6.98 (d, 2H, J = 8.0 Hz), 6.89 (d, 2H, J = 8.4 Hz); 13C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 157.7, 148.7, 145.2, 138.6, 138.5, 129.5, 119.2, 117.4, 90.0.

elements.content: To a Pyrex glass tube (15 cm in length, 7 mm in inner diameter) were added Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (5 mg, 0.02 mmol), 1,4-H2NDC (2 mg, 0.01 mmol), and ppvppa (7 mg, 0.02 mmol) in 2 mL of H2O and 1 mL of MeCN. The tube was sealed and heated in an oven at 150 °C for 1 day and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/60 min to form yellow crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with EtOH, and dried in air. Yield: 6.5 mg (48% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C35H24CdN4O4: C, 61.98; H, 3.65; N, 8.24%. Found: C, 62.09; H, 3.57; N, 8.28%. IR (KBr disk): 3063 (m), 1636 (w), 1600 (s), 1586 (s), 1552 (m), 1432 (s), 1405 (s), 1353 (s), 1331 (s), 787 (m), 547 (m) cm–1. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 70 °C): δ = 9.03 (d, 2H, J = 4.0 Hz), 8.54 (d, 2H, J = 4.0 Hz), 8.26 (d, 2H, J = 4.0 Hz), 8.00 (d, 2H, J = 4.0 Hz), 7.71 (m, 2H), 7.65 (d, 2H, J = 8.0 Hz), 7.56 (m, 4H), 7.20 (d, 2H, J = 16.0 Hz), 7.10 (d, 2H, J = 8.0 Hz), 7.06 (m, 2H), 7.00 (d, 2H, J = 8.0 Hz). The signals of the 13C NMR spectrum of 1 were very weak because of its very low solubility in hot DMSO-d 6 (70 °C).

elements.content: Single crystals of 1 and ppvppa suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly from the above preparations. The measurement of 1 and ppvppa were made on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer using an enhanced X-ray source Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) (1) or a Xcalibur, Atlas, Gemini diffractometer by using enhanced X-ray source Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) (ppvppa). Each single crystal was mounted on a glass fiber with grease and cooled in a liquid nitrogen stream at 153 K for 1 and 223 K for ppvppa. Diffraction data were collected at a ω mode with a detector distance of 35 mm to the crystal. Cell parameters were refined by using the Bruker-SAINT software package and the program CrysAlisPro, Agilent Technologies (Version 1.171.36.28). The collected data were reduced by using the program CrysAlisPro, and absorption corrections (multiscan) were applied. The reflection data were also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.

X-ray Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystals of 1 and ppvppa suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly from the above preparations. The measurement of 1 and ppvppa were made on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer using an enhanced X-ray source Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) (1) or a Xcalibur, Atlas, Gemini diffractometer by using enhanced X-ray source Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) (ppvppa). Each single crystal was mounted on a glass fiber with grease and cooled in a liquid nitrogen stream at 153 K for 1 and 223 K for ppvppa. Diffraction data were collected at a ω mode with a detector distance of 35 mm to the crystal. Cell parameters were refined by using the Bruker-SAINT software package and the program CrysAlisPro, Agilent Technologies (Version 1.171.36.28). The collected data were reduced by using the program CrysAlisPro, and absorption corrections (multiscan) were applied. The reflection data were also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.

elements.content: The crystal structures of 1 and ppvppa were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods with the SHELXL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms were introduced at the calculated positions and included in the structure-factor calculations. A summary of key crystallographic data for 1 and ppvppa is summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1 are listed in Table .

Ligand ppvppa was prepared in two steps using modified literature procedures. As shown in Scheme , the first step involved the CuI-catalyzed cross-coupling reaction of 1,4-diiodobenzene with dipyridylamine in refluxing DMF to give 4-(2,2′-dipyridylamino)-phenyl iodide as a white microcrystalline substance in about 60% yield. The 1H NMR spectrum of 4-(2,2′-dipyridylamino)-phenyl iodide shows the multiplets at δ = 7.69 and 6.89 ppm, which are ascribed to the four protons of the phenyl group. The peaks at δ = 8.23, 7.05, and 6.98 ppm are assigned as the protons of two pyridin-2-yl rings (). The 13C NMR spectrum of 4-(2,2′-dipyridylamino)-phenyl iodide reveals that the peaks at δ = 145.2, 138.5, 129.5, 90.0 ppm are assigned as carbons of the phenyl group, while those located at δ = 157.7, 148.7, 138.6, 119.2, 117.4 ppm are attributed to the carbons of two pyridin-2-yl rings (). In a second step, the Heck reaction of 4-(2,2′-dipyridylamino)-phenyl iodide with 4-ethynylpyridine catalyzed by palladium­(II) acetate and PPh3 in the presence of Et3N at 105 °C for 72 h gave ppvppa in 52% yield. This ligand is soluble in common organic solvents such as CH2Cl2, CHCl3, MeCN, DMF, and DMSO. The high-resolution positive-ion mass spectrum of ppvppa exhibits one cationic peak at m/z = 351.1625 for [C23H19N4 + H]+ (calculated m/z = 351.1610) (). The 1H NMR spectrum of ppvppa exhibits the multiplets at δ = 7.55 ppm and the doublet at δ = 7.20 ppm, which are assigned as the protons of the vinyl group in ppvppa. The signal at δ = 7.65 ppm and the doublets at δ = 7.10 ppm are ascribed to the four protons of the phenyl group. The signals at δ = 8.54 and 7.55 ppm are assigned as the protons of the pyridin-4-yl ring. The doublets/multiplets at δ = 8.26, 7.71, 7.06, and 7.00 ppm belong to the protons of two pyridin-2-yl rings (). The 13C NMR spectrum of ppvppa shows the signals at δ = 132.8 and 125.8 ppm that can be assignable to the carbons of the vinyl group, while those at δ = 145.6, 133.2, 128.6, and 127.0 ppm belong to the carbons of the phenyl ring in ppvppa. The peaks at δ = 150.4, 144.8, and 121.2 ppm are assigned as the carbons of the pyridin-4-yl ring in ppvppa, while those at δ = 157.8, 148.7, 138.4, 119.1, and 117.5 ppm are assumed to be the carbons of pyridin-2-yl rings in ppvppa (). The identity of ppvppa is confirmed by the X-ray crystallography (Figure ). Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that the phenyl group and pyridin-4-yl ring are coplanar and conjugated by vinyl group. The two 2-pyridyl rings are not coplanar with a dihedral angle of 47.18°.

elements.content: Hydrothermal reaction of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with 1,4-H2NDC and ppvppa in H2O/MeCN (v/v = 1/1) at 150 °C in a sealed Pyrex glass tube for 24 h afforded yellow crystals of 1 in 29% yield. The solvent and temperature did exert a significant influence on the formation of complex 1. Attempts to run the similar reactions in EtOH/MeCN or H2O/EtOH led to the formation of an unidentified precipitate that was insoluble in common solvents. Intriguingly, when the H2O/MeCN volume ratio was changed from 1/1 to 2/1, the yield of 1 was increased from 29% to 48%. Performing the reaction at 170 °C produced 1 in a lower yield. Compound 1 is stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents such as CHCl3, CH2Cl2, CH3CN, H2O, CH3OH, THF, benzene, DMSO and DMF. After many attempts, we could dissolve a very little of 1 by heating in hot DMSO-d 6 (70 °C) and managed to detect the weak 1H NMR signals for 1. The peaks at δ = 9.03, 8.00, 7.56, and 7.20 ppm are ascribed to the six protons of the 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate group, while those at δ = 8.54, 8.26, 7.71, 7.65, 7.56, 7.20, 7.10, 7.06, and 7.00 ppm are assignable to the protons of ppvppa in 1 (). However, we still could not obtain readable 13C NMR data for 1 due to its very low solubility in such a hot DMSO-d 6. The positive-ion ESI-MS of 1 in DMSO revealed that only one peak exists at m/z = 351.1604, which can be assigned to the [ppvppa + H]+ ion (). The elemental analysis of 1 is in agreement with its chemical formula. Its IR spectrum exhibits strong absorption bands at 1552–1612 cm–1 and 1308–1450 cm–1 attributable to the coordinated carboxyl group of 1,4-NDC. The thermal stability of 1 was also studied by the thermogravimetric differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) technique. TG analysis () reveals that 1 is stable up 350 °C. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the bulk sample of 1 are consistent with the simulated patterns generated from the single crystal data of 1 (Figure ). The identity of 1 is further confirmed by single crystal X-ray analysis.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca, and the asymmetric unit contains one independent {Cd­(ppvppa)­(1,4-NDC)} molecule. As shown in Figure a, each Cd center is octahedrally coordinated by four O atoms from two 1,4-NDC ligands and two N atoms from two ppvppa ligands. Two Cd atoms are bridged by two ppvppa ligands to form a dimeric [Cd2(ppvppa)2] unit. Each ppvppa ligand in 1 takes a μ-η1(N)-η1(N) coordination mode (pyridin-4-yl ring and one of two pyridin-2-yl rings), and the other pyridin-2-yl ring remains uncoordinated. These [Cd2(ppvppa)2] fragments are linked to four neighbors by four 1,4-NDC bridges to generate a 2D honeycomb network with each window size of 16.94 × 19.56 Å2 (Figure b). The mean Cd–N bond length (2.311(16) Å) in 1 is shorter than that observed in [Cd­(tpcb)0.5­(1,3-BDC)] n (tpcb = tetrakis­(4-pyridyl)­cyclobutane; 1,3-BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) (2.326(4) Å), but longer than the corresponding one in {[Cd3(btc)2­(bimb)2]·2H2O} n (btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate; bimb = 4,4′-bis­(1-imidazolyl)­biphenyl) (2.267(3) Å). The average Cd–O bond length of 2.392(14) Å is longer than that in [Cd­(tpcb)0.5­(1,3-BDC)] n (2.337(4) Å), but shorter than the one found in [Cd­(H2ttac)­bpp] n (H2ttac = 1,1′,2′,1″-terphenyl-4,4′,4″,5′-tetracarboxylate; bpp = 1,3-bis­(4-pyridyl)­propane) (2.588 Å).

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties of 1 along with ppvppa ligand in the solid state at room temperature are investigated (Figure ). The solid state UV–vis spectra of ppvppa and 1 exhibits a strong and broad absorption with maxima values ranging from 200 to 430 nm and a long absorption tail to ca. 700 nm (). Compound 1 exhibits a strong emission at 478 nm when excited at 419 nm. This emission band can be assigned to a ligand-centered emission, because almost identical emission is observed at 418 nm (λex = 370 nm) for the free ppvppa. Compared with that of ppvppa, the emission maxima of 1 is red-shifted, which may be due to be the strong electronic coupling between the neighboring ligands through Cd­(II) ions. A finely ground sample of 1 (2 mg) was suspended in 2 mL of various solvents (CH2Cl2, THF, EtOH, DMF, MeCN, and water) and sonicated for 1 h, and the emission was observed. The solvent molecules exert a significant influence on the emission of 1. Upon excitation, the solvent molecules can rearrange according to the excited state dipole vector and stabilize the excited state. The more polar the solvent molecule, the more the excited state is stabilized. Such an effect results in an increased red shift of the emission spectrum in more polar solvents. The emission maxima in high polar solvents (H2O, EtOH, DMF, MeCN) are red-shifted relative to those in lower polar solvents (THF, CH2Cl2). As depicted in Figure , the emission maxima in organic solvents are slightly blue-shifted relative to that of the solid sample. Interestingly, the suspension of 1 in H2O shows the emission with the maximum at 468 nm coupled with a shoulder at 560 nm. The higher energy emission band is close to the value of the solid sample, while the lower-energy one in water is referred to a twisted intramolecular charge transfer. We then test the emission of 1 in non-nitroaromatics and nitroaromatics upon excitation at 330 nm. The photoluminescence intensities are largely dependent on the substituent groups. The emission maxima of 1 is also blue-shifted in dichlorobenzene, toluene. Significant quenching of fluorescence intensity was observed in nitrobenzene (NB). The fluorescence quenching can be attributed to the photoinduced electron transfer from an excited CPs to the highly electron-deficient NB adsorbed on the surface of 1. The fluorescence quenching of 1 is similar to that reported for other fluorescent CPs and MOFs. Because the luminescence quenching is related to the electron-withdrawing -NO2 group, 1 can be used as a chemical sensor for selective sensing of nitroaromatics. The fluorescence detection experiments were carried out with a suspension of 1 in water. The nitro-substituted organic compound such as 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 4-nitrophenol, 4-nitroaniline, or nitrobenzene was added to an emulsion of 1 (2 mg) in H2O (2 mL). These nitro-compounds reduced the photoluminescent intensity of the emulsion of 1 to different degrees (Figure ). The order of quenching efficiency was 2,4-DNP > 4-nitrophenol > 4-nitroaniline > nitrobenzene with the highest quenching efficiency (QE = (1 – F/F 0) × 100% (F 0 and F are the luminescence intensities before and after the addition of nitro derivatives, respectively)) of 91% for 40 ppm 2,4-DNP in H2O solution. The higher quenching efficiency for 2,4-DNP compared to the other nitro-compounds indicate a high selectivity for 2,4-DNP (Figure ). The intensity of energy transfer is related to the spectral overlap between the absorption spectra of the nitro derivatives and the emission spectrum of 1 to a certain extent, which means more overlap would cause more luminescence quenching. As shown in Figure , the absorption spectrum of 2,4-DNP displays more overlap with the emission spectrum of 1 than those of 4-nitroaniline, nitrophenol, and nitrobenzene. According to the results, the order of the overlap area is in agreement with the order of quenching efficiency, which is 2,4-DNP > 4-nitrophenol > 4-nitroaniline > nitrobenzene.

The photoluminescent properties of 1 along with ppvppa ligand in the solid state at room temperature are investigated (Figure ). The solid state UV-vis spectra of ppvppa and 1 exhibits a strong and broad absorption with maxima values ranging from 200 to 430 nm and a long absorption tail to ca. 700 nm (). Compound 1 exhibits a strong emission at 478 nm when excited at 419 nm. This emission band can be assigned to a ligand-centered emission, because almost identical emission is observed at 418 nm (λex = 370 nm) for the free ppvppa. Compared with that of ppvppa, the emission maxima of 1 is red-shifted, which may be due to be the strong electronic coupling between the neighboring ligands through Cd(II) ions. A finely ground sample of 1 (2 mg) was suspended in 2 mL of various solvents (CH2Cl2, THF, EtOH, DMF, MeCN, and water) and sonicated for 1 h, and the emission was observed. The solvent molecules exert a significant influence on the emission of 1. Upon excitation, the solvent molecules can rearrange according to the excited state dipole vector and stabilize the excited state. The more polar the solvent molecule, the more the excited state is stabilized. Such an effect results in an increased red shift of the emission spectrum in more polar solvents. The emission maxima in high polar solvents (H2O, EtOH, DMF, MeCN) are red-shifted relative to those in lower polar solvents (THF, CH2Cl2). As depicted in Figure , the emission maxima in organic solvents are slightly blue-shifted relative to that of the solid sample. Interestingly, the suspension of 1 in H2O shows the emission with the maximum at 468 nm coupled with a shoulder at 560 nm. The higher energy emission band is close to the value of the solid sample, while the lower-energy one in water is referred to a twisted intramolecular charge transfer. We then test the emission of 1 in non-nitroaromatics and nitroaromatics upon excitation at 330 nm. The photoluminescence intensities are largely dependent on the substituent groups. The emission maxima of 1 is also blue-shifted in dichlorobenzene, toluene. Significant quenching of fluorescence intensity was observed in nitrobenzene (NB). The fluorescence quenching can be attributed to the photoinduced electron transfer from an excited CPs to the highly electron-deficient NB adsorbed on the surface of 1. The fluorescence quenching of 1 is similar to that reported for other fluorescent CPs and MOFs. Because the luminescence quenching is related to the electron-withdrawing -NO2 group, 1 can be used as a chemical sensor for selective sensing of nitroaromatics. The fluorescence detection experiments were carried out with a suspension of 1 in water. The nitro-substituted organic compound such as 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), 4-nitrophenol, 4-nitroaniline, or nitrobenzene was added to an emulsion of 1 (2 mg) in H2O (2 mL). The order of quenching efficiency was 2,4-DNP > 4-nitrophenol > 4-nitroaniline > nitrobenzene with the highest quenching efficiency (QE = (1 - F/F 0) × 100% (F 0 and F are the luminescence intensities before and after the addition of nitro derivatives, respectively)) of 91% for 40 ppm 2,4-DNP in H2O solution. The higher quenching efficiency for 2,4-DNP compared to the other nitro-compounds indicate a high selectivity for 2,4-DNP (Figure ). The intensity of energy transfer is related to the spectral overlap between the absorption spectra of the nitro derivatives and the emission spectrum of 1 to a certain extent, which means more overlap would cause more luminescence quenching. As shown in Figure , the absorption spectrum of 2,4-DNP displays more overlap with the emission spectrum of 1 than those of 4-nitroaniline, nitrophenol, and nitrobenzene. According to the results, the order of the overlap area is in agreement with the order of quenching efficiency, which is 2,4-DNP > 4-nitrophenol > 4-nitroaniline > nitrobenzene.

elements.content: In order to gain insight into the fluorescence quenching process, complex 1 was titrated with various nitro aromatics in H2O at room temperature. The Stern–Volmer (SV) plots in water were used to calculate the quenching constant and analyze the quenching efficiency of the analytes (Figure ) using the SV equation (I 0/I) = K sv[A] + 1, where I and I 0 are the fluorescence intensities after and before addition of the analyte, K sv is the quenching constant (M–1), and [A] is the molar concentration of the analyte. A quenching constant of 118 M–1 was obtained for 2,4-DNP, 15 M–1 for 4-nitrophenol, 13 M–1 for 4-nitroaniline, and 1 M–1 for nitrobenzene (Figure ). Notably, the quenching constant for 2,4-DNP was found to be much higher than those of 4-nitroaniline, 4-nitrophenol, and nitrobenzene, demonstrating high selectivity for 2,4-DNP. The SV plots for 2,4-DNP in water displayed an almost linear relationship at low concentrations and strayed from linearity at higher concentrations. The nonlinear nature of the SV plots of 2,4-DNP can be attribute to self-absorption or the energy-transfer process, implying that the fluorescence quenching process is occurred by both dynamic and static quenching. 4-Nitroaniline, 4-nitrophenol, and nitrobenzene displayed similar linear SV plots. The quenching efficiency was estimated to be 70 ppm (97%) for 2,4-DNP, 120 ppm (95%) for 4-nitrophenol, 120 ppm (94%) for 4-nitroaniline, and 800 ppm (94%) for nitrobenzene (Figure and ). These results demonstrate that compound 1 has good sensitivity for detecting small amounts of 2,4-DNP in H2O solution and superior to that reported for metal coordination complexes (about 300 ppm for [Cd2Cl­(H2O)­(L)]­·4.5DMA (DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide, H3L = 4,4′,4″-((2,2′,2″-(nitrilotris­(methylene))­tris­(1H-benzo­[d]­imidazole-2,1-diyl))­tris­(methylene))­tribenzoic acid) or 2000 ppm for Cd­(L)·(HDMA)2­(DMF)­(H2O)3 and Zn­(L)·­(HDMA)2­(DMF)­(H2O)6 (H4L = bis­(3,5-dicarboxy-phenyl)­terephthalamide) toward nitroaromatics with two -NO2 groups). The detection sensitivity by 1 toward nitrobenzene was also superior to other CPs (3050 ppm for [Cd­(H2ttac)­bpp] n (H4ttac = 1,1′,2′,1″-terphenyl-4,4′,4″,5′-tetracarboxylic acid; bpp = 1,3-bis­(4-pyridyl)­propane) or 1000 ppm for [(CH3)2NH2]4­[Cd3(H2L)] (H12L = 5,5′,5″,5‴,5],5]′-[1,2,3,4,5,6-phenylhexamethoxyl]­hexaisophthalic acid).

The quenching efficiency was estimated to be 70 ppm (97%) for 2,4-DNP, 120 ppm (95%) for 4-nitrophenol, 120 ppm (94%) for 4-nitroaniline, and 800 ppm (94%) for nitrobenzene (Figure  and ). These results demonstrate that compound 1 has good sensitivity for detecting small amounts of 2,4-DNP in H2O solution and superior to that reported for metal coordination complexes (about 300 ppm for [Cd2Cl(H2O)(L)]⋅4.5DMA (DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide, H3L = 4,4',4"-((2,2',2"-(nitrilotris(methylene))tris(1H-benzo[d]imidazole-2,1-diyl))tris(methylene))tribenzoic acid) or 2000 ppm for Cd(L)⋅(HDMA)2(DMF)(H2O)3 and Zn(L)⋅(HDMA)2(DMF)(H2O)6 (H4L = bis(3,5-dicarboxy-phenyl)terephthalamide) toward nitroaromatics with two -NO2 groups). The detection sensitivity by 1 toward nitrobenzene was also superior to other CPs (3050 ppm for [Cd(H2ttac)bpp] n  (H4ttac = 1,1',2',1"-terphenyl-4,4',4",5'-tetracarboxylic acid; bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane) or 1000 ppm for [(CH3)2NH2]4[Cd3(H2L)] (H12L = 5,5',5",5‴,5],5]'-[1,2,3,4,5,6-phenylhexamethoxyl]hexaisophthalic acid).

elements.content: The further investigation was done for examining the relationship of luminescence quenching degree with the concentration of 2,4-DNP. Complex 1 was dispersed in water (2 mg/2 mL), and then increasing amounts of 2,4-DNP were added. The quenching efficiency grows hugely over the low concentrations of 2,4-DNP and gently grows at higher concentrations (Figure ). At a concentration of 70 ppm, the luminescence intensity is nearly completely quenched with a quenching efficiency of 97% (Figure ). A good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.983) exists between the fluorescence quenching efficiency and the concentration of nitrobenzene over the range of 2–20 ppm (inset of Figure ). The emission maxima of 1 is slightly red-shifted (about 6 nm) with the addition of 2,4-DNP, indicating an electrostatic interaction. The hydroxyl group in 2,4-DNP can interact with the N atom of uncoordinated pyridyl ring in 1. Thus, compound 1 exhibits better selective detection of 2,4-DNP among other nitro derivatives in water through the energy transfer, electron transfer, and electrostatic interaction. After immersion in H2O, 2,4-DNP, 4-nitrophenol, 4-nitroaniline, and nitrobenzene for 24 h, crystals of 1 were collected by filtration, washed with EtOH, dried in a vacuum, and then characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). The PXRD patterns of 2,4-DNP-immersed 1 and H2O-immersed 1 indicate that 1 remains stable in H2O and in the presence of 2,4-DNP (Figure ). Meanwhile, PXRD patterns of 1 after immersing in other nitro solvents for 24 h also confirmed that the original framework structure is retained (). Complex 1 can be regenerated by centrifugation of the solution after use and washing several times with H2O. Remarkably, the initial fluorescence intensity is essentially retained even after six cycles suggesting a high photostability and reversibility of 1 for detection applications (Figure ).

elements.content: In summary, a new π-electron-rich bis­(2-pyridyl)-amine ligand ppvppa has been successfully assembled with the Cd­(II) ion to yield a robust 2D coordination polymer 1. Each ppvppa in 1 adopts a μ-η1(N)-η1(N) mode to link two Cd atoms, forming a [Cd2(μ-ppvppa)2] unit. These units are connected by 1,4-NDC ligands to form a 2D honeycomb network. The resulting CP material emits blue luminescence, which is quenched by nitro aromatics. A dispersed suspension of 1 in H2O also displays strong fluorescence emission and exhibits good selectivity and sensitivity toward 2,4-DNP. Though Cd is not the right metal from the viewpoint of green chemistry, complex 1 is rather robust and insoluble in water, which endows it to be a good candidate for the aforementioned optical detection system. Of course, the luminescent CPs with “more green” metals such as Fe, Zn, Mg, and Li can be designed and prepared and work as practical responsive sensors for the highly efficient detection of pollutants in water. Studies in this respect are currently underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a new π-electron-rich bis(2-pyridyl)-amine ligand ppvppa has been successfully assembled with the Cd(II) ion to yield a robust 2D coordination polymer 1. Each ppvppa in 1 adopts a μ-η1(N)-η1(N) mode to link two Cd atoms, forming a [Cd2(μ-ppvppa)2] unit. These units are connected by 1,4-NDC ligands to form a 2D honeycomb network. The resulting CP material emits blue luminescence, which is quenched by nitro aromatics. A dispersed suspension of 1 in H2O also displays strong fluorescence emission and exhibits good selectivity and sensitivity toward 2,4-DNP. Though Cd is not the right metal from the viewpoint of green chemistry, complex 1 is rather robust and insoluble in water, which endows it to be a good candidate for the aforementioned optical detection system. Of course, the luminescent CPs with "more green" metals such as Fe, Zn, Mg, and Li can be designed and prepared and work as practical responsive sensors for the highly efficient detection of pollutants in water. Studies in this respect are currently underway in our laboratory.

A mixture of 2,2′-dipyridylamine (1.97 g, 11.5 mmol), 1,4-diiodobenzene (7.588 g, 23 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.41 g, 2 mmol), cesium carbonate (1.15 g, 3.5 mmol), and copper­(I) iodide (0.152 g, 0.8 mmol) in 100 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) was placed in a 500 mL round-bottom flask and heated to 160 °C under N2 atmosphere for 48 h. The reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature, and DMF was removed under reduced pressure. Dichloromethane and water were used to dissolve the solids, and the organic phase was separated and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The crude product was purified by flash silica gel column chromatography using petroleum ether and ethyl acetate (1:10) as the eluent to afford a white solid. Yield: 2.64 g (60%). mp 98.8–99.6 °C; IR (KBr disk): 3009 (m), 1586 (m), 1567 (m), 1530 (m), 1483 (m), 1465 (s), 1428 (s), 1329 (s), 1270 (m), 1151 (m), 1096 (m), 1052 (m), 1006 (m), 988 (m), 823 (m), 762 (m), 735 (m), 714 (m), 647 (m), 615 (m), 525 (m), 509 (m) cm–1 (). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 8.23 (d, 2H, J = 4.0 Hz), 7.69 (m, 4H), 7.05 (m, 2H), 6.98 (d, 2H, J = 8.0 Hz), 6.89 (d, 2H, J = 8.4 Hz); 13C NMR (100 MHz, DMSO-d 6): δ = 157.7, 148.7, 145.2, 138.6, 138.5, 129.5, 119.2, 117.4, 90.0.

Preparation of <italic toggle="yes">N</italic>-(Pyridin-2-yl)-<italic toggle="yes">N</italic>-(4-(2-(pyridin-4-yl)­vinyl)­phenyl)­pyridin-2-amine (ppvppa)

A mixture containing 4-(2,2′-dipyridylamino)-phenyl iodide (0.35 g, 0.9 mmol), 4-ethynylpyridine (0.115 g, 1.1 mmol), palladium­(II) acetate (12.75 mg, 0.06 mmol), and PPh3 (12.75 mg, 0.05 mmol) was placed in a N2-purged Schlenk tube. Triethylamine (3 mL) was added and the solution heated to 105 °C with stirring for 72 h. After cooling to room temperature, the mixture was partitioned between dichloromethane and water. The organic phase was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The crude product was purified by flash silica gel column chromatography petroleum ether and ethyl acetate (2:7) to afford ppvppa as a yellow solid. Yield: 0.17 mg (52%). mp 157.7–158.5 °C; Anal. Calcd for C23H18N4: C, 78.83; H, 5.18; N, 15.99%. Found: C, 78.92; H, 5.21; N, 15.87%. Preparation of {Cd­(ppvppa)­(1,4-NDC)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

To a Pyrex glass tube (15 cm in length, 7 mm in inner diameter) were added Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (5 mg, 0.02 mmol), 1,4-H2NDC (2 mg, 0.01 mmol), and ppvppa (7 mg, 0.02 mmol) in 2 mL of H2O and 1 mL of MeCN. The tube was sealed and heated in an oven at 150 °C for 1 day and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/60 min to form yellow crystals, which were collected by filtration, washed with EtOH, and dried in air. Yield: 6.5 mg (48% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C35H24CdN4O4: C, 61.98; H, 3.65; N, 8.24%. Found: C, 62.09; H, 3.57; N, 8.28%. IR (KBr disk): 3063 (m), 1636 (w), 1600 (s), 1586 (s), 1552 (m), 1432 (s), 1405 (s), 1353 (s), 1331 (s), 787 (m), 547 (m) cm–1. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 70 °C): δ = 9.03 (d, 2H, J = 4.0 Hz), 8.54 (d, 2H, J = 4.0 Hz), 8.26 (d, 2H, J = 4.0 Hz), 8.00 (d, 2H, J = 4.0 Hz), 7.71 (m, 2H), 7.65 (d, 2H, J = 8.0 Hz), 7.56 (m, 4H), 7.20 (d, 2H, J = 16.0 Hz), 7.10 (d, 2H, J = 8.0 Hz), 7.06 (m, 2H), 7.00 (d, 2H, J = 8.0 Hz). The signals of the 13C NMR spectrum of 1 were very weak because of its very low solubility in hot DMSO-d 6 (70 °C).
